sn48.53:4.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
sn48.53:4.3: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
sn48.53:4.4: “Mendicants, is there a way that a mendicant who is a trainee, standing at the level of a trainee, can understand that they are a trainee? And that a mendicant who is a master, standing at the level of a master, can understand that they are a master?”
sn48.53:5.1: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. …”
sn48.53:5.2: “There is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee, standing at the level of a trainee, can understand that they are a trainee, and that a mendicant who is a master, standing at the level of a master, can understand that they are a master.
sn48.53:6.1: And what is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee can understand that they are a trainee?
sn48.53:6.2: It’s when a mendicant who is a trainee truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
sn48.53:6.3: This is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee can understand that they are a trainee.
sn48.53:7.1: Furthermore, a mendicant who is a trainee reflects:
sn48.53:7.2: ‘Is there any other ascetic or brahmin elsewhere whose teaching is as true, as real, as accurate as that of the Buddha?’
sn48.53:7.4: ‘There is no other ascetic or brahmin elsewhere whose teaching is as true, as real, as accurate as that of the Buddha.’
sn48.53:7.5: This too is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee can understand that they are a trainee.
sn48.53:8.1: Furthermore, a mendicant who is a trainee understands the five faculties:
sn48.53:8.2: faith, energy, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.
sn48.53:8.3: And although they don’t have direct meditative experience of their destination, apex, fruit, and culmination,
sn48.53:8.5: they do see them with penetrating wisdom.
sn48.53:8.6: This too is a way that a mendicant who is a trainee can understand that they are a trainee.
sn48.53:9.1: And what is the way that a mendicant who is a master can understand that they are a master?
sn48.53:9.2: It’s when a mendicant who is a master understands the five faculties:
sn48.53:9.3: faith, energy, mindfulness, samādhi, and wisdom.
sn48.53:9.4: They have direct meditative experience of their destination, apex, fruit, and culmination,
sn48.53:9.6: and they see them with penetrating wisdom.
sn48.53:9.7: This is a way that a mendicant who is a master can understand that they are a master.
sn48.53:10.1: Furthermore, a mendicant who is a master understands the six faculties:
sn48.53:10.2: eye, ear, nose, tongue, body, and mind.
sn48.53:10.3: They understand: ‘These six faculties will totally and utterly cease without anything left over. And no other six faculties will arise anywhere anyhow.’
sn48.53:10.4: This too is a way that a mendicant who is a master can understand that they are a master.”
